text:
CHRISTINE LIU: I like to think
that I'm so, so self-aware

and so, so proactive, and
I'll make all the changes
that I need to make.
But I'm not that person.

I need feedback,
I need something

to tell me that I need to
change, and then I'll react.

When I ask for feedback it tends
to be really, really casual.

So, I've been making
these YouTube videos.
What do you think?

I know that's not the best
way to ask for feedback,

but that's usually how
it ends up coming out.

And then the response
is something like--
[APPLAUSE AND CHEERING]
Stuff like this is not helpful.
I want you to give me the truth.

That said, it does make
me a little anxious.

Like, what if it's
feedback I didn't expect?

What if it's something
that really hurts?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I want to learn three
key things here.

How do I ask for
quality feedback?

How do I react to the feedback,
especially if it's painful?

And ultimately, how do
I put it into action?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Before we get
started, this episode
is brought to you by Microsoft.

Microsoft's mission is
to empower every person

and organization on the
planet to achieve more.

But it's nothing without
the people behind it.

Watch and read some of
the stories of the people

behind the mission
at microsoftlife.com.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA:
Hearing something that's
not so great-- it does stink.

And you could even
say, I just need
some time to reflect on this.

And that gives you
the time and space.

You may need to go and vent with
a friend, and that's fine, too.
[LAUGHS] We're only human.

CHRISTINE LIU: That's
Octavia Goredema.

She's a career coach, and
she's the founder of Twenty Ten

Agency based in Los
Angeles, California.

They focus on career advancement
and accelerating diversity
at big companies.

She helps people improve on
workplace skills, especially

ones that are super
foundational, like feedback.

From a tactical perspective,
how do I ask for feedback?

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA:
So the first thing

is don't be afraid
to ask for feedback.

Asking for feedback
is great because it

shows that you are proactive
and you are accountable.

So don't be afraid
to use your voice.

But the first thing to
do is to perhaps-- when

you've assessed what your needs
are, is to think about timing.

And when you know
your needs, you'll

be able to know when you
need to ask for the feedback.

Because you don't want
to be asking your manager

for feedback when
they're rushing

to work on another project,
or they're distracted.

You want to make sure
you're the timing is right.

And then also when possible,
try and have a conversation.

If you're dropping a question
in Slack or an email,

you might not get
the same response

that you'll get if you're
actually having a dialogue.

CHRISTINE LIU: Let's say
I get positive feedback.

What's the right way
to respond to that?

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Sometimes,
depending on your personality,

receiving positive feedback
can feel a little awkward.

And the one thing
I always say is

don't diminish what
that person is saying.
Don't say, oh, it was nothing.

And of course if other
people are involved,

acknowledge other
people as well.

But say thank you,
accept it, and keep it.

I always recommend,
keep that feedback.

If it was something given to
you in a meeting or verbally,
jot it down somewhere safe.

If it's an email or a message,
file it away and keep it

in one place, because the time
will come where you might want

to go back and reflect on
that, or when you're preparing
for a performance review.

CHRISTINE LIU: I always thought
it was kind of creepy to keep
things like that, but--

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA:
No, no, no, no, no.
Keep them, because we forget.

CHRISTINE LIU: So,
when I get feedback

that I wasn't expecting,
my heart starts racing.

I can feel the blood
throbbing in my ears.

What if it's something
that affects me deeply?

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: It can
be common to feel defensive
when that happens.
That can be a human reaction.

But do your best to
try and curb that

by listening, thanking the
person for the feedback,

and you could even
say, I just need
some time to reflect on this.

And that gives you
the time and space.

You may need to go and vent with
a friend, and that's fine too.
We're only human.

And then the thing to
remember is it's not
what you did or didn't do.
It's actually what you do next.

You can turn a bad situation
into something great
if you take action.

Once you've reflected, you
want to go back to the person

and thank them for
the feedback and say,

here are some of the things I'm
looking to do to address this.

Is there anything else
that you would recommend?

CHRISTINE LIU: What if
you receive feedback
and you disagree with it?

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA:
I think being open
and objective really matters.

Listening and
reflecting matters,

but then considering where
that feedback is coming from.

CHRISTINE LIU: Octavia
says that the relationship
with your manager is key.

If you disagree
with the feedback,

it's possible you don't quite
see eye to eye with your boss,

and you might disagree
on fundamental stuff

like your role or
your responsibilities.

If that's true,
it's probably time

to have a conversation
about that.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Oh
my goodness, our roles

can change so fast, and
demands can change so fast.

And you might be operating
in a certain way,

and all of a sudden
expectations have shifted

and that might not have
been communicated clearly.

CHRISTINE LIU: What do you
do if you are really open,

and you're listening, but
the other party is like,

oh, you're doing a great
job, there are no problems.

There's really not
a lot of substance.

Is there something you can
ask, or are there magic words
that kick in that next gear?

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: It
comes back to your needs
though, Christine.

So, if you need the feedback for
validation, that's one thing.

If you need that
feedback so that you

can grow into another
role, that's different.

And so you might need to provide
the context for that person

as to why you're
asking for the feedback
so that they understand.
CHRISTINE LIU: OK.

I feel ready for accepting
feedback, good or bad.

And also I have some
techniques up my sleeve

to extract more usable feedback
than the ordinary, "great job."

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Just know
that, yes, feedback matters,

but good and bad feedback
are building blocks
to help you do your best work.
CHRISTINE LIU: Practice time.

When I'm looking for feedback
for this show, Christine

vs. Work, I think that
I have two main needs.

So, one, I want to
improve the show.

And then two, I personally want
to develop my hosting skills.

I want to get way more
comfortable and more effective.

We're going to have a
meeting on the schedule.

It's not going to be
like a casual slack.

I want it to be a time that
we can have, prepare for it.

OK, so let's say I
get great feedback.

I should not throw
it under the rug.
Take it.
Take the complement.

Do not say, oh, yeah,
that was nothing.

Let's say I get feedback that
kind of surprises me, or kind
of hits a little close to home.
So, take a deep breath.

Acknowledge, thank
them for the feedback.
Thank you.

I really appreciate
that feedback.

I might need some
time to reflect on it.
So, buying time.

Do not look upset or
disappointed or angry or
defensive.
OK.

You set up a follow-up meeting,
and you can say, hey, thank you
so much.

I really appreciate
that feedback.
It gave me a lot to think about.

So I put together a plan
and maybe some actions

that I could take to address
those issues that you raised.
And practice is good.

It's good to say
those words out loud,
and everything's going to be OK.

It's not going to be
the end of the world,
even though I feel that way.
I think-- are we ready?
Am I ready?
Let's do this.
[BELL CLANGS]

I wanted to sit down with
you because I would really

appreciate your feedback,
as the editor of Ascend,
for Christine vs Work.

I'm looking for
feedback from you

particularly
because I appreciate

your point of view
and sensibility
on this type of content.

But for me, I want the
show itself to be awesome,

and also I just
want to make sure

that I'm representing and being
the best host that I can be.
So I always want to improve.

I don't want to pretend
that I have nowhere to grow.

So I'm always looking
for suggestions or ways

that I can be a better
host to the show.

PAIGE COHEN: Thank
you for asking.

I really appreciate
you taking the time
to listen to my feedback.

And I mean, to be
honest, I've been

looking through
your episodes and I

am finding it hard to find a lot
of critique to say any, I mean,

quote unquote
"negative feedback."

I'm like, I don't want
to pull at strings

and just give it to
you if I don't see it.

I think that you're just doing
an awesome job as a host.

I think like you're
really opening the doors

for like what HBR can be on
YouTube through the Ascend
brand.
CHRISTINE LIU: Yeah, no.

I totally understand
what you're saying,

and I really appreciate
that feedback.

It sounds like it's
mostly positive.

Do you have just like, uh, I
guess the least favorite parts
of the shows?

PAIGE COHEN: I think when
it's just the interviews,
it's helpful to hear the advice.

But if I don't see the
advice put into action,

I am usually less
engaged in the episode.

CHRISTINE LIU: Do you have
any ideas or suggestions

on how I, as the host, could
make the interview level up
a little bit?

PAIGE COHEN: Like,
as a viewer there's

a lot of times when you want
to know about, like, oh,
but that's really good advice.

But what about this
situation or this situation
I find myself in?

And sort of considering the
most difficult scenarios

that you might be able to
bring up with people to really
challenge them.

CHRISTINE LIU: Anything
else you want to add?

PAIGE COHEN: While there
is always room to improve,

I think that you're
just really killing it.

And so I just hope you walk away
feeling really good about that.

CHRISTINE LIU: I have my two
bits of feedback-- usable
feedback from Paige.
Thank you so much.

The most important thing
is that I work on it,

I show that I am trying to
improve it, and then display,

hey, these are the
things that I did

and this is a marked improvement
from when we talked about this.

I'm hearing Octavia's
voice in my head

where it's like, it's not
what the feedback is--

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: It's
actually what you do next.

CHRISTINE LIU: Speaking of
feedback, I really value yours.

So what do you think, dear
viewer, about the show?

What do you think
about me as the host?

What do you think
about all these things?

I read every single comment
you guys leave, so please,
be honest.
You can tell me anything.

I accept it, and
I will work on it.
So, go for it.

If you're still
watching, one, thank you.
But two, I'm really curious--
what do you want me to explore?

What problems do
you have at work?
I'd love to solve them.
Please leave a comment.
I'd love to hear your thoughts.

And if you have any other
ideas, throw them my way.
All right, peace out.
